content: Alfred Stieglitz took a series of photographs of clouds, known as the "Equivalents" series. He created a total of 228 photographs in this series, between 1922 and 1935. The photographs were all taken from the window of his New York City apartment, and were intended to capture the ever-changing patterns and moods of the sky. The "Equivalents" series is considered one of Stieglitz's most important and influential bodies of work, and is widely regarded as a key contribution to the development of modernist photography.
